I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  A consultation mission to assess the feasibility of a capacity development technical 
assistance (TA) project for capacity building for disaster risk finance was fielded in December 
2011. Following discussions with the Government of Bangladesh and development partners in 
Bangladesh, the mission concluded that the proposed TA is in line with the Asian Development 
Bank (ADB) country partnership strategy, 2011–2015 for Bangladesh. In addition, the proposed 
TA complements the disaster risk management assistance currently being provided by other 
development partners.1 On 19 December 2011, the government formally requested ADB to 
include the TA in ADB’s nonlending pipeline for 2012, and the related fact-finding mission was 
fielded from 27 February to 1 March 2012. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 
1.2 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
2.  Bangladesh is a disaster-prone country, with floods being the most frequent and poses 
the most severe danger.3 In an average year, river floods affect 20% of the country’s surface 
area, and in extreme years, this can reach 68%. In 2004, an unusually severe flood inundated 
38%  of  the  country,  resulting  in  747  deaths,  economic  losses  of  $2.2  billion,  and  public 
rehabilitation costs of $1.5 billion. Cyclones also constitute a major risk for Bangladesh. In 2007, 
Cyclone Sidr swept through the southwestern coastal areas, resulting in 3,363 deaths, 55,282 
injuries, and $2.3 billion in total economic damage.4 Bangladesh is also susceptible to other 
dangers, including drought, earthquakes, river bank erosion, tsunamis, arsenic contamination of 
groundwater, soil salinity, and health pandemics. Because Bangladesh is a densely populated, 
low-income  country,  natural  calamities  cause  disproportionate  and  adverse  impacts  to  its 
population and economy that could delay achievement of the Millennium Development Goals. 
 
3.  The government has made substantial efforts in disaster risk management and instituted 
national disaster management structures and legislation both nationally and subnationally. The 
National Disaster Management Council, which is headed by the Prime Minister, formulates and 
reviews  the  country’s  disaster  management  policies  and  issues  directives  to  guide 
implementation of those policies. The Ministry of Food and Disaster Management (MFDA) is the 
national focal point for disaster management that oversees the Disaster Management and Relief 
Division.  The  National  Disaster  Plan,  2010–2015,  which  was  approved  in  2010,  sets 
comprehensive structures and policy actions for disaster risk management. 
 
4.  Despite the establishment of a comprehensive disaster risk management structure, the 
application of financial protection in disaster risk management is still limited. In response to 
disaster events, the government generally allocates budgetary funds for disaster relief and 
rehabilitation from a contingency account or reallocates funds across categories of expenditure. 
This  often  disrupts  the  implementation  of  critical  public  investment  projects  necessary  for 
sustained economic growth. Further, private sector participation in disaster risk finance is almost 
nonexistent due to the absence of reliable parametric disaster risk models and limited financial 
sector development. 
 
5.  To cope better with disaster-related rehabilitation and reconstruction costs, both public 
and  private  sectors  increasingly  applied  ex  ante  disaster-related  financial  risk  transfer

mechanisms since the early 1990s. Disaster risk financing requires developing different options 
according to the nature of the disaster, the probability of occurrence, and the potential loss of, or 
impact on, life and physical capital. Two operations that can be included in these options are (i) 
contingency budget financing, and (ii) disaster risk financing instruments. In particular, disaster 
risk financing instruments can include insurance; reinsurance; insurance-linked securities (e.g., 
catastrophe  bonds,  also  known  as  CAT  bonds); 5  contingency  drawdown  options;  or  a 
combination of these. A diverse group of disaster microinsurance programs are also being 
tested to provide disaster protection to low-income populations. Variations and combinations of 
different  types  of  disaster  risk  finance  can  be  applied  to  provide  a  comprehensive  set  of 
solutions to the range of disaster risk profiles facing Bangladesh (i.e., from high frequency–low 
severity to low frequency–high severity events). 
 
6.  If reliable institutional disaster risk financing can provide timely access to funds, the 
resulting relief and rehabilitation interventions could save lives and reduce economic losses. 
Other  potential  advantages  include  (i)  increased  government  control  over  the  financing  of 
disasters, possibly including the immediate and timely availability of funds by amortizing risks 
over time, which reduces budget shocks; (ii) increased ability for the government to set its own 
priorities in the management of relief and rehabilitation; and (iii) increased transparency in the 
delivery of relief and reconstruction projects. Increased public insurance, in whatever form, 
could  also  stimulate  increased  private  cover  by  familiarizing  private  sector  firms  with  the 
Bangladesh market. Disaster risk financing can also provide significant benefits by helping to 
price risk and by providing mechanisms to incentivize investments in risk-reduction measures, 
for example, through premium discounts. 
 
7.  In the country partnership strategy (footnote 1), disaster risk mitigation is one of the 
seven key strategic themes in ADB assistance for Bangladesh. The strategies include support 
for  disaster  risk  reduction  by  extending  support  through  financing  measures  to  reduce 
Bangladesh’s exposure to disaster risk. Disaster risk management is also a key development 
goal  of  the  government.  The  poverty  reduction  strategy  paper  for  Bangladesh  includes 
commitments  to  ensure  comprehensive  disaster  risk  management  and  environmental 
sustainability so that these concerns can be incorporated into the national development process 
by  2015.6 Bangladesh’s  Sixth  Five-Year  Plan,  2011–2015  also  promotes  climate  change 
adaptation and disaster risk reduction. 
 
8.  The United Nations Development Programme (UNDP), together with a consortium of 
other development partners, including the Department for International Development of the 
United Kingdom, the European Union, and the Swedish International Development Cooperation 
Agency, has been implementing the Comprehensive Disaster Management Program (CDMP) II 
since 2011 . The CDMP II aims to reduce Bangladesh’s vulnerability to adverse natural hazards 
and extreme events, including the impacts of climate change, through risk management. It has 
six  outcome  areas:  (i)  the  development  of  institutions  to  implement  comprehensive  risk 
reduction programs, (ii) reduced risk to rural populations, (iii) reduced risk to urban populations, 
(iv) improved disaster preparedness, (v) minimized disaster impacts on development funding, 
and (vi) community-level adaptation to extreme climate events. 
                                                 
5  The catastrophe bond, or CAT bond, is a fixed income security that pays periodic coupons to the investor during 
the life of the bond and insures the sponsor of the bond against a predefined set of natural disasters such as 
earthquakes or hurricanes. If a covered event occurs during the bond’s life, the sponsoring country retains the 
bond principal to fund emergency relief and reconstruction work. CAT bonds are an efficient tool for countries to 
transfer specific layers of their natural disaster risk to the capital markets and a viable alternative to standard 
insurance or reinsurance coverage to access and benefit from hedging interest and capacity within markets. 
6  Government of Bangladesh, Planning Commission, General Economics Division. 2005. Bangladesh–Unlocking the 
Potential–National Strategy for Accelerated Poverty Reduction. Dhaka.

3
9.  In 2011, the World Bank, in collaboration with the Institute of Water Modeling and the 
Center for Environmental and Geographic Information Services, carried out a study in disaster 
risk management to estimate the adaptation costs from the increased risks of cyclones and 
inland monsoon floods. The study reported that the adaptation costs for Bangladesh will be 
about  $5.7  billion  by  2050.  In  addition,  the  Japan  International  Cooperation  Agency  has 
provided a grant assistance to develop a typhoon warning system. While the assistance by 
other development partners has provided comprehensive support for disaster risk management 
in  Bangladesh,  disaster  risk  financing  has  not  yet  been  addressed.  The  TA  will  seek  to 
coordinate the disaster risk management efforts of development partners. 
 
10.  The TA will enhance Bangladesh’s disaster risk preparedness by building up public and 
private capacity to develop disaster risk finance solutions and by fostering links between the 
public and private sectors in disaster risk mitigation. The TA will focus on formulating strategies 
to introduce a set of suitable disaster risk finance solutions in Bangladesh based on experiences 
in other regions, including in developed countries such as the United States and Japan. The TA 
will also strive to maximize transparency and accountability in the use of funds for disaster risk 
management. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
11.  The expected impact of the TA will be improved government preparedness for disaster 
relief and rehabilitation. The outcome will be that the government is better positioned and 
equipped to plan disaster relief and rehabilitation. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
12.  The TA will focus on providing fiscal and financial protection to Bangladesh against 
natural disasters by designing a midterm disaster risk financing strategy, potentially for both 
sovereign  and  non-sovereign  (which  could  include  the  needs  of  local  governments, 
homeowners, small businesses, and poor communities). An effective financing strategy hinges 
on several factors, including (i) the nature of the disaster risk profile, (ii) the funding gap, and (iii) 
the cost and feasibility of available instruments. The funding gap in turn depends on the likely 
levels of need (including contingent liabilities) and access to financing after a disaster (for relief, 
recovery, and reconstruction). Below is the framework of analysis.

4   
13.  Following this framework, the TA will have four outputs: 
 
(i)  Output 1: Catastrophe risk profiling of Bangladesh carried out. A risk profile 
will  be  created  that  (i)  identifies  risks  across  the  two  continuum  of  high 
frequency–low severity and low frequency–high severity disaster events affecting 
Bangladesh, and (ii) indicates several scenarios for likely climate change impacts 
on the frequency and intensity of climate-related disaster events over the next 30 
years. The TA will draw on existing information and studies carried out by the 
government with support from UNDP and other development partners and will fill 
in gaps to develop a comprehensive risk profile for the nation, districts and/or 
cities and communities, subject to availability of data. The types of disasters to 
be covered under the TA will be determined based on government priorities and 
likely cover frequently occurring disasters. 
(ii)  Output  2:  Funding  gaps  for  disaster  response  estimated.  In  estimating 
funding gaps, the time dimension must also be considered since relief operations 
require  resources  that  can  be  mobilized  immediately  after  a  disaster,  while 
recovery and reconstruction needs require significantly larger resources over the 
longer run. Therefore, the design of efficient financing solutions must take time 
into account to ensure that funding requirements are matched with the capacity 
to use funds when required. Moreover, the funding requirements and funding 
gaps will also depend on the government’s own responsibilities in the event of a 
disaster. This will provide a signal on the part of the risk that will not be covered, 
encouraging those bearing that risk to take precautionary measures. 
(iii)  Output  3:  Detailed  design  of  the  risk  finance  solutions  developed. The 
range of available solutions includes, among others, contingency budgeting, risk 
insurance  facilities  (including  microinsurance),  and  capital  market-linked  risk 
finance solutions (e.g., CAT bonds). Through a broad consultation process led by 
the government and facilitated by the TA, the TA will review potential options for 
risk financing solutions and select a set of instruments and interventions for 
inclusion in a medium-term disaster risk financing strategy, based on priority 
needs, feasibility, and cost-effectiveness. As part of the feasibility analysis, the 
TA will also identify the legal and administrative frameworks necessary to enable 
effective uses of each instrument under consideration. Finally, the TA will provide 
practical road maps for creating the selected instruments (including potential 
interventions to facilitate market provision of these instruments). 
(iv)  Output  4:  Knowledge-sharing  workshops  on  disaster  risk  finance 
conducted.  In-country  and  regional  workshops  will  be  conducted  on  risk 
financing needs and potential solutions. The workshops will also be an integral 
part of the consultation and decision-making for selecting among risk financing 
options and developing a medium-term strategy for implementing the selected 
solutions.  In  addition,  knowledge  products,  including  publications,  will  be 
produced for wider dissemination. The TA will hold consultation discussions with 
international reinsurance and capital markets stakeholders for potential public–
private links in disaster risk finance based on strategies developed by the TA. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
14.  The TA is estimated to cost $600,000 of which $500,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction and administrated by ADB. The government will 
provide  counterpart  support  in  the  form  of  counterpart  staff  and  other  support  activities, 
including access to data, as needed. The cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2.

5
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
15.  MFDA,  through  its  Disaster  Management  and  Relief  Division,  will  be  the  executing 
agency. Along with MFDA, the Banks and Financial Institutions Division of the Ministry of 
Finance (MOF) will provide guidance and input to the TA, especially for the component on the 
design of risk finance instruments. The executing agency will appoint a TA coordinator who will 
coordinate and supervise the TA consultant team for all outputs. A TA steering committee will 
be formed, chaired by the secretary of the MFDA’s Disaster Management and Relief Division 
and comprising representatives from (i) the External Relations Division, MOF; (ii) the Banks and 
Financial Institutions Division, MOF; (iii) the Disaster Management Bureau; (iv) the Planning 
Commission; (v) the CDMP, UNDP; and (vi) the TA coordinator. The TA steering committee will 
meet at least quarterly to provide necessary inputs and guidance to the TA team. The TA 
consultant  team  will  coordinate  with  the  Securities  and  Exchange  Commission  on  the 
component for the design of risk finance instruments. It will also consult other institutions, such 
as the Bangladesh Water Development Board, as needed. 
 
16.  The government will provide (i) all relevant documents, data, statistics, information, and 
maps that are at its disposal; (ii) appropriate and qualified counterpart staff (including the 
provision of their field per diem and field transportation); (iii) the TA coordinator to be assigned 
before  the  consultants’  mobilization;  and  (iv)  logistical  assistance  for  the  workshops  and 
meetings. 
 
17.  The TA will be implemented over 24 months, from 31 March 2013 to 31 March 2015. 
The TA will require approximately 10 person-months of international consultant inputs and 10 
person-months of national consultant inputs. The consultants should have expertise in disaster 
risk finance, disaster risk profiling, public disaster risk finance, the financial sector and capital 
markets, public management or disaster risk management, and capacity development and 
knowledge management. ADB will engage the consultants in accordance with its Guidelines on 
the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). A team of consultants will be 
recruited  under  one  package  using  the  quality-  and  cost-based  selection  method,  with  a 
standard quality-cost ratio of 80:20. Given the highly complex and technical nature of the 
assignment, the TA requires a full technical proposal for consultant recruitment. The terms of 
reference for consultants are in Appendix 3. 
 
18.  The TA consultant team will organize an in-country information dissemination workshop 
and a regional workshop for the government and other public and private agencies. There will 
also be information dissemination and consultation meetings with international reinsurance and 
capital market stakeholders on the TA findings and recommendations. The outputs of the TA will 
be widely disseminated online as well as through publications. Disbursements under the TA will 
be made in accordance with ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as 
amended from time to time). 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
19.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 to the Government 
of Bangladesh to be financed on a grant basis by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction for 
Capacity Building for Disaster Risk Finance, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  The  capacity  development  technical  assistance  (TA)  will  require  approximately  10 
person-months of international consultants and 10 person-months of national consultants. The 
consultants will be recruited through a firm using the quality- and cost-based selection method. 
Given  the  highly  complex  and  technical  nature  of  the  assignment,  recruitment  with  a  full 
technical proposal is proposed. 
 
A.  Disaster  Risk  Finance  Specialist  and/or  Team  Leader  (international,  5  person-
months) 
2.  The specialist will have at least 10 years of extensive experience in insurance, capital 
market, or banking as well as significant exposure to disaster risk finance. As team leader, the 
specialist will: 
 
(i)  Conduct an overall assessment of the financial sector (i.e., insurance, capital 
market, and banking) in view of introducing disaster risk finance solutions as 
viable risk transfer options. 
(ii)  Oversee  and  contribute  to  the  development  of  risk  profile  and  funding  gap 
analysis outputs to be completed by the disaster risk profiling specialist and the 
public disaster risk finance specialist. 
(iii)  Conduct in-country consultation meetings and workshops to assess the degree 
of awareness, need, and demand for disaster risk finance among central and 
local government stakeholders. 
(iv)  Conduct, with the help of the public disaster risk finance specialist, feasibility 
assessments of various risk finance solutions, looking at the degree of alignment 
with medium- to long-term fiscal framework of the Government of Bangladesh, 
expected gains, and cost effectiveness. 
(v)  Based on the above assessment and consultations, develop recommendations 
on a set of disaster risk finance solutions suitable to Bangladesh and a strategy 
for pursuing these solutions. Recommendations shall include, but not be limited 
to,  capacity  development  needs,  policy  and  regulatory  reform  requirements, 
partnerships,  implementation  modalities,  and  action  plans.  Preliminary 
expectations  are  that  the  recommendations  could  include  the  following  risk 
finance solutions: (a) public finance contingency budgeting; (b) capital market-
linked  disaster  risk  finance  solutions  (i.e.,  catastrophe  bonds  and  sovereign 
catastrophe insurance); and (c) disaster risk microinsurance. 
(vi)  Conduct dissemination workshops in the region and produce related knowledge 
products, including a summary publication outlining the proposed disaster risk 
finance solutions and related implementation strategy. 
(vii)  Lead the coordination and logistical arrangements for the in-country and regional 
workshops on disaster risk finance as well as seminars and training programs. 
(viii)  Lead the production of necessary materials for seminars and workshops and 
arrangements for public relations to enable effective information dissemination on 
disaster risk finance. 
(ix)  Supervise the production and ensure the quality of a publication on disaster risk 
finance to the Asian Development Bank’s satisfaction. 
(x)  Manage and supervise the consultant team members and ensure the quality of 
their outputs.

Appendix 3  11 
B.  Disaster Risk Profiling Specialist (international, 3 person-months) 
3.  The  specialist  will  have  more  than  10  years  of  experience  relating  to  disaster  risk 
management. Familiarity with the financial sector and private financial institutions would be an 
advantage. The ability to analyze water-related disasters, such as typhoons and floods, as well 
as a familiarity with hydrology, especially probability analysis and climate change impacts, are 
essential. Working closely with the team leader, the specialist will: 
 
(i)  Review the existing risk models and hazard maps and assess and categorize 
disaster risks by type and severity at national and district levels. 
(ii)  Identify and seek to fill gaps in existing risk data. 
(iii)  Develop improved data on exposure and vulnerability. 
(iv)  Integrate data on likely scenarios for climate risks over the next 30 years. 
(v)  Combine results into a comprehensive risk profile, addressing key indicators of 
hazard exposure; physical, social, and economic vulnerability; and estimates of 
potential disaster losses. 
(vi)  With the international disaster risk finance specialist and team leader, identify 
capacity development and training needs for disaster risk finance and carry out 
capacity development activities based on the government’s priorities. 
(vii)  Provide guidance and ensure that the quality of TA outputs by the disaster risk 
finance specialist and the public disaster risk finance specialist are consistent 
with the country’s legal, regulatory, and policy structures. 
 
C.  Public Disaster Risk Finance Specialist (international, 2 person-months) 
 
4.  The specialist will have more than 10 years of experience in public finance and public 
management, in particular in developing countries. The specialist will have in-depth knowledge 
of and exposure to disaster risk management. Under the supervision of the team leader, the 
specialist will: 
 
(i)  Assess  current  public  resource  management  practices  in  disaster  risk 
management based on a review of relevant policy documents, legislation, and 
strategies, especially with respect to their effectiveness and applicability in view 
of existing risk models and loss estimates. 
(ii)  Analyze the division of fiscal roles and responsibilities for disaster response and 
risk management among the central and local governments in Bangladesh. 
(iii)  In consultation with the relevant government agencies, estimate the contingent 
liability of the government for post-disaster assistance under different disaster 
scenarios as well as the expected annual loss based on historic loss data and 
projections given future risk patterns to develop a funding gap analysis. 
(iv)  In consultation with the central and local governments and private stakeholders, 
develop  recommendations  for  the  inclusion  of  contingent  budgeting,  reserve 
funds,1 and other potential disaster risk financing solutions within a medium-term 
disaster  risk  financing  strategy  to  be  adopted  by  the  government. 
Recommendations shall include, but not be limited to, implementation modalities, 
rules, regulations, reporting, and monitoring. 
                                                 
1  Preliminary suggestions have been made to the ADB project team to examine the feasibility of a (i) National 
Disaster Response and Recovery Fund, (ii) National Risk Reduction Fund, (iii) Financing Sectoral Plans, and (iv) 
District/Upazila/Union/Paurashava/City Corporation Disaster Management Fund.

12  Appendix 3 
 
 
(v)  Assist the team leader to assess the financial and fiscal implications for the 
proposed  disaster  risk  finance  solutions  in  a  medium-  to  long-term  fiscal 
framework of the government. 
(vi)  Based  on  the  assessment  above,  develop  implementation  strategies  for 
contingent budgeting and other disaster risk financing solutions to be adopted 
under the government’s budgetary processes. 
 
D.  Financial Sector and Capital Market Specialist (national, 4 person-months) 
5.  The specialist will have more than 10 years of experience in banking, insurance, or 
capital market institutions, and will be familiar with sovereign debt or insurance instruments. The 
specialist will also have substantial knowledge of and experience in the microfinance sector. 
Knowledge of and exposure to disaster risk finance would be an advantage. Working under the 
guidance of the international disaster risk finance specialist, the specialist will: 
(i)  Guide and advise the international disaster risk finance specialist in the review of 
policies,  the  legal  and  regulatory  framework,  financial  institutions,  and  the 
potential for application of capital market-linked disaster risk financing as well as 
disaster risk microinsurance solutions in Bangladesh. 
(ii)  Coordinate with the financial sector, including the insurance and capital market 
sectors,  to  organize  discussion  forums  for  the  development  of  strategies  to 
initiate  or  strengthen  capital  market-linked  disaster  risk  finance  solutions  in 
Bangladesh. 
(iii)  Liaise with the Micro Credit Regulatory Authority, microfinance institutions, and 
community  groups,  and  assess  the  needs  and  demands  for  disaster  risk 
microinsurance schemes. In support of the international disaster risk finance 
specialist, devise options and implementation strategies for a practical disaster 
risk microinsurance scheme potentially linked with the international reinsurance 
market. 
(iv)  Formulate a public–private partnership component to be incorporated within the 
disaster risk financing strategy to be developed under the TA. 
(v)  Advise  the  international  disaster  risk  finance  specialist  on  specific  capacity 
development and support areas to the domestic insurance sector, microfinance 
institutions, and other relevant institutions for the adoption of capital market-
linked disaster risk finance solutions and disaster risk microinsurance. 
 
E.  Public  Management  and/or  Disaster  Risk  Management  Specialist  (national,  4 
person-months) 
6.  The  specialist  will  have  more  than  10  years  of  experience  in  public  resource 
management as well as substantial knowledge in disaster risk management. Working closely 
with the international public disaster risk finance specialist, the specialist will: 
 
(i)  Guide  and  advise  the  international  public  disaster  risk  finance  specialist  on 
policies, legislation, regulations, and practices on disaster public management in 
Bangladesh. 
(ii)  Liaise with relevant institutions on public finance and disaster risk management 
and coordinate meetings and discussions as appropriate. 
(iii)  Identify opportunities to link planned disaster risk financing solutions to incentives 
for disaster risk reduction and climate change adaptation as part of a disaster risk 
financing strategy.

Appendix 3  13 
(iv)  With  the  international  public  disaster  risk  finance  specialist,  identify  capacity 
development and training needs for public finance and disaster risk management 
institutions and carry out capacity development and training activities based on 
the government’s priorities. 
(v)  Provide guidance and ensure that the quality of outputs by the disaster risk 
finance specialist and the public disaster risk finance specialist are consistent 
with the country’s legal, regulatory, and policy structures. 
 
F.  Capacity Development and Knowledge Management Specialist (national, 2 person-
months) 
 
7.  The specialist will have at least 5 years of experience in organizing and facilitating 
seminars, workshops, and information dissemination. Working with the international capacity 
development and knowledge management specialist, the specialist will: 
 
(i)  Coordinate and provide logistical support for the planned in-country and regional 
seminars and workshops, as well as periodic training and capacity development 
activities. 
(ii)  Assist in the development of knowledge products. 
(iii)  Assist in production and dissemination activities, as guided by the international 
capacity development and knowledge management specialists.
